heading: 3.3.2 Check Normality with Shapiro-Wilk Test and Histograms
text: need check normality groups separately. can filter groups:use dollar sign $ point R particular column. example, using shapiro.test(redcow$int) saying run Shapiro Test redcow data set specific column called intAgain, want p-values significant. non-significant p-value means data roughly normally distributed. p-value significant, issue indicates data normally distributed.reporting Shapiro-Wilk test, just need report test statistics (w = XX) p-value. example look like:W = 0.98, p = .875You can also visually check data quick histogram:Check plots panel, use blue arrow switch two plots.

#first create a data set that contains the control group only

  filter(drink == "control")
#then run the test

#then create a data set that contains Red Cow drinkers only

  filter(drink == "redcow")
#then run the test

hist(control$int)

heading: 4.4 Exercise 4: Check Assumptions
text: Run ANOVA modelBefore start looking assumptions, need run store initial ANOVA model.Checking NormalityFirst, look see assumption normality met. look three things.QQ-PlotThe histogramThe Shapiro-Wilk testChecking SphericityTo check sphericity, need produce model output.Look output find: “Mauchly Tests Sphericity”.provide test statistic, reported using W = XX.XXIt provide p-value statistic. test, non-significant p-value means assumption met. non-significant p-value one larger value .05. significant p-value one smaller .05.looks though p-value smaller .05 assumption violated. uh-oh!
code:
mod <- aov_ez(id = "id",
              dv = "memory",
              within = "time",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = mydata)
#testing normality, looking at normal distribution of residuals from the model.
residuals <- residuals(mod) #pulls residuals from the model

# produce QQ-Plot
qqPlot(residuals) #produces a qq-plot of residuals

# produce histogram of residuals
hist(residuals, breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals", col = "lightblue") 

# Shapiro test on residuals
shapiro.test(residuals) #Shapiro test for residuals
summary(mod) # provides the output of the main ANOVA model with Sphericity output.

heading: 10.5 Snowman Plot
text:
Now real serious complicated plotting…ggplot() really powerful many things can .’ll need packages.Copy paste code snowman plot…
code quite long expand section copy , run .code adapted :DrMowinckels (Dec 11, 2019) wanna build snowman?. Retrieved https://drmowinckels.io/blog/2019/--wanna-build--snowman/. DOI: https://www.doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13273500Well Done. reached end workshop
code:
install.packages("ggforce") # you'll need this package if not installed
library(ggforce)
library(tidyverse) # if not already loaded
snowman <- tibble(y = 1:3, x = 0, r = 1:3)
p <- ggplot(snowman) + 
  geom_circle(aes(x0 = x, y0 = y, r = r)) + 
  coord_fixed()
snowman <- tibble(x = 0, r = 3:1) %>% 
  mutate(y =(r^2) *-1)
p <- ggplot(snowman) + 
  geom_circle(aes(x0 = x, y0 = y, r = r),
              fill = "white", 
              colour = "lightgrey") + 
  coord_fixed()
face <- tibble(x = c(-0.5, 0.5, 0),
               y = c(.75, .75, 1)*-1,
  type = c("eye", "eye", "nose"),
  colour = c("black","black", "coral2"))
p <- p + geom_point(data = face, show.legend = FALSE,
             aes(x = x, y = y, 
                 shape = type, colour = I(colour)))
p <- p + geom_arc(aes(x0 = snowman$x[nrow(snowman)], 
               y0 = snowman$y[nrow(snowman)], 
               start = 2.2, end = 4, r=.6))
arms <- tibble(x = c(-3.5, -2, -3, -3.4, -3, -3.2, 2, 3.6, 3.1, 3.5, 3.1, 3.3),
               y = c(-3, -3.7, -3.2, -3.5, -3.2, -2.8, -3.7, -3, -3.2, -3.4, -3.1, -2.5),
    side = c(rep("left arm", 2),
           rep("left finger1", 2),
           rep("left finger2", 2),
           rep("right arm", 2),
           rep("right finger1", 2),
           rep("right finger2", 2)))
p <- p + geom_line(data = arms, 
            size = 1.5, lineend = "round",
            aes(x = x, y = y, group = side))
p <- p + geom_point(aes(x = 0, y = -3:-5), size = 4)
tophat <- tibble(x = c(-1, -0.9, -0.3, -0.4, 1.1, 0.8, 1.5, 1.4),
                 y = c(0, .25, .15, 1, .75, -0.04, -.25, -.5),
                 id = 1)
p <- p + geom_polygon(data = tophat, 
               aes(x = x, y = y, group = id))
scarf <- tibble(x = c(-0.5, 0.3, 0.4, 0.3, 0.5),
                y = c(-2, -2, -3, -2, -2))
p <- p + geom_line(data = scarf, size = 3, 
            lineend="round",
            colour = "firebrick4",
            aes(x = x, y = y))
p + theme_void() +
    theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "skyblue3"))

clean_mydata$q5_3 <- 6 - clean_mydata$q5_3
clean_mydata$q5_5 <- 6 - clean_mydata$q5_5
clean_mydata$q5_6 <- 6 - clean_mydata$q5_6

heading: 11.9 8. Calculate the mean scores for the two questionnaires
text:
moment cleaned data file individual question responses.
However, participant need mean score questionnaire/scale.participant need:overall (mean) academic anxiety questionnaire score.overall (mean) academic anxiety questionnaire score.overall (mean) procrastination questionnaire score.overall (mean) procrastination questionnaire score.can create new variables means using code .Let’s explain code bit bit can adapt future:clean_mydata <- clean_mydata %>% specify data file create new column.mutate() add new column.anxiety = want call new column.rowMeans calculate means across items/questions.select certain number items.starts_with("q4_") variable begins q4_ counted (e.g., q4_1 q4_11).na.rm = TRUE important tell R ignore missing values calculating mean.
code:
# Select and calculate the anxiety scale score
clean_mydata <- clean_mydata %>%
  mutate(anxiety = rowMeans(select(., starts_with("q4_")), na.rm = TRUE))

# Select and calculate the procrastination scale score
clean_mydata <- clean_mydata %>%
  mutate(procrastination = rowMeans(select(., starts_with("q5_")), na.rm = TRUE))
